On Tue, 21 Jun 2005, jason r tibbetts wrote:
> Teemu Kanstr�n wrote:
> > Hello all,
> >
> >  I am trying to gather some data from the execution of JUnit test
> > cases. For this purpose I wish to add a piece of code to be called after
> > each test has been run. I noticed that TestResult has a possibility to
> > add such a piece of code through TestListener.
> >
> > However, adding the listener requires that I have access to the
> > TestResult objects created. And these in turn are created in the
> > TestRunner instances. And if I run my tests from an IDE or Ant, the
> > runner used is out of my control.
> >
> > I am thinking I could just modify the TestResult to always add my
> > listener in its constructor or something similar (maybe a static
> > listener..). But I am not sure if this is the best solution.
> >
> > So I guess my questions are:
> >  -Did I understand the code correctly?
> >  -Is there a way for me to easily add such a listener, hopefully without
> >   messing too much with the JUnit sources?
> >  -Can anyone think of reasons why modifying TestResult to contain my
> > listener would not work? Are there some cases or environments that modify
> > the execution so they dont use the standard TestResult? For example Ant,
> > etc..
>
> Is this something that can't just be put into tearDown(), which is
> invoked after each test runs, regardless of whether it succeeded?

 Hmm didn't really think about that. I'll have to try it out. Sound so
simple it might work :).

Perhaps if I just modify the tearDown() method in JUnit's TestCase class
to execute my data collection method it should work without me needing to
modify the different projects code.

Thanks,
